column2: Twelve million men's suits have moved from sewing rooms and warehouses through retail stores in the three months since the Office of Price Administration allowed higher prices, but it is still as difficult to buy a suit as it was in March.

Stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., voted at their annual meeting here yesterday to authorize a two-for-one split of the common stock, of which 3,752,136 shares are now outstanding, and approved an increase in authorized number of shares from 4,455,800 shares to 9,000,000 shares of $1 par value.

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., June 18--Sharp criticism of the Government's handling of the food situation marked the second-day sessions of the convention of Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., meeting here today.

THAT bright and slickly polished ornament of modern English letters, Evelyn Waugh, is no longer the too-little-appreciated pet of a few readers who delight in sophisticated wit and satiric buffoonery.

CHICAGO, June 18--Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, declared here today that he would fight all efforts of the House Military Affairs Committee to amend his bill for a five-man civilian commission on atomic energy to include two military members.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 18-- Mrs. Margaret Mosher Capron, prominent Montclair clubwoman and civic leader, wife of C. Alexander Capron, New York lawyer, died here last night in her home at 41 Bradford Way.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)-- Representative August H. Andresen, Republican, of Minnesota, told the House today that failure of Administration officials to make proper plans was "bringing the country face to face with the most serious food crisis in history."

WASHINGTON, June 18--A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, reporting on a tour last year of Europe and the Near East, called today for an end to "our unwise appeasement methods" in dealing with Russia and recommended a meeting between President Truman and Premier Stalin for a "frank, across-the-table exchange of sentiment."

VIENNA, June 19--Austria, already badly affected by Russian seizures, suddenly has been faced with a demand by the Allied Control Council in Berlin for the return to Germany of German investments in this country.

Lashed to the mast for six innings by the no-hit pitching of Ewell (Blackie) Blackwell, the Giants, haunted by the beckoning spectre of last place, rose in wrath to smite down their tormentor with four runs in the seventh for a 4to-3 decision over the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

A broad cross-section of the city's business, industry and trade adopted by a unanimous vote yesterday a resolution, addressed to Mayor O'Dwyer, urging the creaation of a traffic authority to deal with the widespread congestion in the city.
REMINISCENCES and novels about the vanished Victorian and Edwardian eras are as dependable British exports as tweeds and lecturers and marmalade.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (U.P.)-- The House committee on surplus war property disposal will begin "a full-blown inquiry" into such sales within two weeks, its chairman, Roger C. Slaughter of Missouri, said tonight.

It was evident early in the evening that no one would be crushed in the rush for tickets at the Stadium last night. As a matter of fact, an hour before the opening preliminary, there were fewer customers in sight than one would find there on a dull Monday afternoon when the Yankees are playing the Athletics--or something.

WASHINGTON, June 19--President Truman strongly urged a speedy appropriation of the remaining $465,000,000 authorized for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in his seventh quarterly report on UNRRA, submitted to Congress today.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Harold D. Smith, budget director who in the last seven years policed the spending of more Federal billions than any man in history, was named today vice president of the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development on the...

WASHINGTON, June 19--Continuing to strengthen the influence of military men in the proposed atomic energy commission, the House Military Affairs Committee approved an amendment to the McMahon bill today that would permit the Army, with Presidential authority, to manufacture atomic bombs.
Underwriting managers here received clearance from the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for the public offering of stocks and debentures as follows:

The Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that seventy-eight retail merchants and restaurateurs in Brooklyn had paid into the Uhited States Treasury $3,765 to settle overcharge claims in the last two weeks.

After the designation for the Republican nomination for Representative of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. by all the Assembly district leaders of the Seventeenth Congressional District, Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for renomination in the primaries of all political parties.

A "round-up" of United States merchant vessels shows some 389 ships are occupied in United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administrative service, while an additional 768 are transporting essential "national program" cargoes for various of the United Nations, it was disclosed yesterday.

All's well in Flatbush again. Not only did the Dodgers blank the Pirates, 7--0, at Ebbets Field yesterday, but Pete Reiser threw a runner out at the plate and Joe Hatten became the first Brooklyn pitcher to last the route and win since Kirby Higbe did it on Memorial Day.

The Sheltering Arms Children's Service had a family of 605 to care for last year. This year it hopes the family will be even bigger, for there are still homeless children in this city who haven't found their foster parents.

The defense contention in the Lustig tax evasion case that a voluntary disclosure of misdeeds was made on March 26, 1945, to William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, was characterized yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Boris Kostelanetz as "a pure and simple hoax."

An offer by the purchaser of the Madison Avenue property between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets, now occupied by St. Joseph's Residence, to postpone formal acquisition of the site indefinitely lest it be a hardship for the hundred young women living there, has been rejected by the Sisters of Mercy.
"He can run but he can't hide." That bit of homespun philosophy was offered in his training camp by Joe Louis less than a fortnight ago.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- The Office of Price Administration today forecast higher retail prices in the 1946 pack of canned fruits and vegetables.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 19 (AP)--Albert Speer, architect of German war industry, began building a defense against war-crimes charges today with the contention that he had performed as a business man and not as a fanatical Nazi and had in time completely broken with Adolf Hitler.
WASHINGTON, June 19--Declaring that "in the flame of World War II the Good Neighbor policy met the supreme test," the Rev....

The Consolidated Grocers Corporation of Chicago, manufacturers, canners and wholesale distributors of food, reported yesterday for the forty-eight weeks ended on June 1, a net income of $2,401,695 after all charges, including taxes and minority interests.

The six-story eighty-four-family apartment house on a plot 190 by 100 feet at 581 Timpson Place, the Bronx, has been sold by the Timpson Place Construction Company to a client of Emil Leepson, attorney.
Except for Joe Louis and Billy Conn, no one experienced much difficulty in getting in the Yankee Stadium last night.

SCRANTON, Pa., June 19-- More than 250 delegates attending the thirteenth annual convention of the American Newspaper Guild were told by United States Secretary of Labor Schwellenbach today that collective bargaining progress by the organization "has made a very real contribution to American labor's mechanisms for improving the position of wage earners."

LONDON, June 19--Nine-tenths of the $25,000,000 that the Allied Governments have made available as an advance on the liquidation of German assets in neutral countries will be used for the rehabilitation and resettlement of German and Austrian Jewish victims of Nazism and the remaining $2,500,000 will go to aid non-Jewish victims.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- The Senate overrode Republican objections and upheld today the increases which its Appropriations Committee made in funds voted by the House for reclamation projects in Western States.
MOSCOW, June 19--A rigorous new disciplinary code for the Red Army, Navy and Air Force has been signed by Prime Minister Stalin, the newspaper Red Star announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 19--The International Trade Conference, which was to have been held this spring or summer, cannot be convened until next spring, informed officials said today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 19-- While carpenters banged their hammers feverishly and cement mixers whirred, the sport of kings was welcomed back to Monmouth Park today. It had been fifty-three years since it left and most of Monmouth County seemed to be on hand to welcome it back for the eighteen-day meeting.
The American Museum of Safety has again recognized in appropriate fashion the splendid record of safety of American railroads by the presentation of the E.H. Harriman Memorial medals and prizes.
Striking modern furniture handfashioned by promising young craftsmen forms an innovation in the summer exhibition previewed yesterday at America House, 485 Madison Avenue.
The stock market surrendered further ground yesterday although losses did not reach the proportions of the preceding session and prices backed down on comparatively light pressure.
Champion Joe Louis weighed 207 pounds and Billy Conn 182 for their heavyweight title fight at Yankee Stadium last night.

The short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined to 867,891 shares on June 14 from the 1,022,399 shares reported a month earlier, the Exchange announced yesterday. The 18 per cent drop reflected the uneven character of trading in the last month.

MOSCOW, June 19--Bearing with him such gems of Soviet literature as "The Adventures of a Cabin Boy" and "Fellow Travelers," Earl Browder, one-time head of the Communist party in the United States, is returning to New York as soon as transportation can be arranged.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 19 --William Y. Dear Jr. of Montclair won the qualifying medal in the men's forty-fourth annual metropolitan golf championship with a one-under-par 35, 36--71 over the hilly and well-groomed Essex County Country Club course today.

DETROIT, June 19--Kim Sigler, a fighting prosecutor, who within the space of thirty months has risen from the role of a small-town lawyer to a man of State-wide eminence, today won the Michigan Republican Gubernational nomination.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (U.P.)-- Fred M. Vinson, Secretary of the Treasury, appeared assured tonight of quick confirmation by the Senate as Chief Justice of the United States.

An excited group of 325 gardeners who farm the Children's Garden sponsored by the New York Plant and Flower Guild in a fourblock area on York Avenue, staged their seventh annual flower show yesterday in the garden cottage at Sixty-fifth Street.

The Soviet Union brought forward yesterday a substitute plan for outlawing atomic bombs by international agreement, subject to final control by the United Nations Security Council--on which Russia, along with the four other great powers, would retain her veto.

Continuing its program of expansion, States Marine Corporation, 90 Broad Street, has joined with Hellenic Lines, Ltd., to form a new Mediterranean service under the name of the American Hellenic Lines, Ltd., it was announced yesterday by Henry D. Mercer, president of States Marine.
The American Jewish Committee urged yesterday in a memorandum to the State Department that the United States recommend to the British Government the immediate admission of 100,000 Jews to...
WASHINGTON, June 19--The problem of getting and keeping the right men in Federal service was illustrated by two events in the Capital today.

Increasing numbers of employers are applying to the New York State Division of Veterans Affairs for permission to establish on-thejob training programs, Dr. Julius Yourman, chief of the division's counseling services, declared yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 19--Retail coal dealers in Pittsburgh are being required to agree to pay to soft-coal producers, retroactive to May 13, any price increases which the Office of Price Administration might grant to meet higher wages, health and welfare fund payments and bonuses granted the country's 400,000 bituminous miners in ending their recent strike.

In a daring hold-up yesterday morning four young thugs, posing as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation entered the home of Max Rabinowitz, 51 East Ninety-sixth Street, Brooklyn, bound three persons to chairs, and then escaped with a small safe containing $1,000 in cash and securities.

Hardy Clothes, Inc., bought the ten-story office and loft building at 27 East Twenty-second Street from a syndicate represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, and will use most of the space for showrooms and offices. The property is assessed at $75,000 and was sold through H. Brinckerhoff MacCully.
TOKYO, June 19--Force was used for the first time this morning in the battle between Tsunego Baba, publisher, and Tomin Suzuki, managing editor, over the control of the newspaper Yomiuri Hochi.

This was no championship bout, because Jet Pilot is off in the West on the gold hunt, but a colt named I Will came up with a knockout punch in the fifty-sixth Great American Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday to score a sparkling victory and put himself in the middle of the fight for honors among the 2-year-olds.

LONDON, June 19 (AP)--Jack Kramer, America's main hope to win the men's singles titles at Wimbledon tennis tourney next week, was seeded No. 2 today and drew R.J. Sandys of Ireland as his first-round opponent.
The International Emergency Food Council, which today supersedes the war-created three-nation Combined Food Board, starts work with the assurance that world-wide famine this summer has been averted.

TOKYO, June 19--Interviews with three new Japanese Cabinet Ministers today indicated that the Government headed by Premier Shigeru Yoshida is approaching the nation's economic problems both realistically and vigorously.

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., June 19--Complete breakdown of the Nation's food distribution system at the retail level is in prospect if official rationing is restored, food industry leaders asserted here today.

PARIS, June 19--Without having yet approached the critical issues of Trieste and disposition of the Italian colonies, the Council of Foreign Ministers remained thoroughly bogged down today in the complexities surrounding minor economic clauses of the Italian treaty.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Herbert Hoover, honorary chairman of President Truman's Famine Emergency Committee, reported today that he had found additional food for hungry lands as the result of "excellent, cooperation" from Latin America.
The nation's gasoline stocks last week decreased 697,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Anglo-American policy on Palestine and the United States' retention of bases in Iceland were interpreted last night by William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, as links in a general conspiracy by this country and Great Britain for a future war against the Soviet Union.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 19-- Miss Maureen Orcutt, defending champion and recent winner of the women's metropolitan championship, today took the lead in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54-hole medal play tournament at the Essex Fells Country Club.

An oil burner of new design, featuring a patented automatic "economy clutch," which was said to yield fuel savings of 10 to 24 per cent in home heating, was demonstrated yesterday by officials of the Gilbert Barker Manufacturing Company, subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) at a press conference in the Hotel New Yorker.
Television carried the Joe LouisBilly Conn heavyweight fight last night to receivers in the metropolitan district, to Philadelphia, Schenectady and Washington.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Eleanor Morton Trask, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hartshorne Trask of 21 East Ninetieth Street and Deer Hill, Cornwall-on-Hudson, to John Maurice Connole, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Connole of Naugatuck, Conn.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19-- Capt. Rawson J. Valentine, USN, a veteran of both world wars, died today at the home of George K. Coleman in suburban Brookline, where he was visiting. His age was 54.

Advertising's use as a tool with which management can sell the company as well as its products is outlined in "The Job Ahead for Business," a thirty-two page booklet which has been prepared and published by the Association of National Advertisers.

WASHINGTON, June 19--A reorganization of the Chinese Army with the help of 1,000 United States Army and Navy experts, as proposed by Gen. George C. Marshall, would have far-reaching results in the rehabilitation of China, Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today.

Just when the Interstate Commerce Commission will act on the request by the railroads for an increase of about 25 per cent in the present freight rates to absorb the recent wage rise is anybody's guess, but it probably will not be delayed much longer. However, the rate situation is somewhat muddled.

The Singer Manufacturing Company had a net profit in 1945 of $14,300,776, equal to $15.89 a share, Sir Douglas Alexander, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday. The net profit for 1944 was $13,897,322 or $15.44 a share.

The six-story building at 254-56 West Sixty-fifth Street, near West End Avenue, was sold by Herbert R. Abels, Aaron Lesser and Richard R. Lewit, trustees, to a buyer who plans to alter and occupy it for his automotive parts business.

The efforts of the Security Council to cope with the problem of Spain were brought to an ironic end on Tuesday, when Russia, bitter foe of the Franco regime, used her veto power to prevent a proposed action against that regime.

Neither the Association of American Railroads nor the regional rate conferences seek to coerce or restrain individual railroads in the adjustment of freight rates, which are subject always to final action of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the State commissions, John E. Tilford, vice president in charge of traffic of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, testified here yesterday in the suit of the State of Georgia against Southern and Eastern Railroads.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 19 (UP)--Dr. Eduard Benes became President of Czechoslovakia for the third time today by a unanimous vote of the new Constituent Parliament.

Coordination of the activities of the city's many public and private agencies engaged in combating crime was urged yesterday by a panel of seven speakers participating in a conference called by Dr. Peter Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction, in the chapel of the City Prison, 125 White Street.
The Gulf States Utilities Company awarded yesterday at competitive sale an issue of $27,000,000 of first mortgag thirty-year bonds to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. Bearing an...

ELKHART, Ind., June 19--The help of the press was sought today in finding a disabled American war veteran who is probably awaiting delivery of a one-handed B flat clarinet he ordered specially built for himself nearly a year ago.
BUENOS AIRES, June 19--The Argentine people are now being told that--despite local propaganda--their Government is not shipping food to starving Europe.

BERLIN, June 18 (Delayed)-- In one four-room flat in the United States sector in Berlin 160 stateless and displaced persons have been huddled for months, without more than the bare necessaries to keep them alive.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 19-- Miss Fanny DeWolf Conklin, a civic leader in Hackensack for many years, died yesterday in her home at 226 Passaic Street at the age of 92.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 19--It wasn't the Fourth of July, but Hoboken celebrated today as it rarely had celebrated before. It was all because exactly a hundred years ago the first game of baseball between organized teams was played on what was Elysian Fields here until that sylvan retreat vanished before the march of industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19-- Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and International Pictures announced today that contracts have been signed under which The Fairbanks Company, newly organized producing concern, will make "The Exile" in association with International this fall.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Col. A. Robert Ginsburgh, now serving as Executive Assistant to the Secretary of War, was decorated today by Secretary Patterson with the Distinguished Service Medal for outstanding contributions while serving in the field in the Pacific area.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19--An aggregate of $967,000,000 of new corporate issues was offered for sale in the United States during the first quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its statistical bulletin for May.
HEWLETT, L.I., June 19--Mrs. Thomas Rudel of Cedar Creek, who yesterday won the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the North Shore Country Club, today turned...
Representatives of sixty-seven nations, fifty-one of them members of the United Nations, met yesterday in this city under U.N. auspices in the largest international health conference ever assembled.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The strategy of sending to the President a temporary labor-curb measure as a substitute for the permanent regulations of the Case bill is in a state of sinking suspension in Congress.

Acting with the support of the Russian bloc, the Arab League's only spokesman in the Economic and Social Council fought vainly yesterday at the Hunter College session to prevent the International Refugee Organization from aiding any immigration to Palestine.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 19 --The Rev. Dr. Forest Preston Hunter, retired Baptist clergyman, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 75.

William Hammatt Davis, former chairman of the War Labor Board and Director of Economic Stabilization from March 7 to Sept. 17, 1945, will be sworn in as a member of the Board of Transportation at 3:30 P.M. today, Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night.

WASHINGTON, June. 19--The mystery of who handed reporters advance copies of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee report criticizing "appeasement" of Russia remained unsolved today, but the row its publication caused continued to furnish Capitol Hill with one of its choicest bits of gossip in years.
The first joint negotiations looking toward a settlement of the three-week-old Hudson Manhattan tube strike will be held at 3:30 P.M. today in Mayor O'Dwyer's office at City Hall.

The question of how to teach about the Soviet Union in New York City's public high schools has created a sharp controversy among social studies teachers, and echoes of the dispute are being heard at the headquarters of the Board of Education, it became known yesterday.
LONDON, June 19--A radio chess match between Great Britain and the Soviet Union, signaling the first radio-telegraphic hook-up between the British Broadcasting Corporation and Moscow Radio, ...
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 19 (AP)--Unless farmers' needs are recognized "we will have a hungry nation," Henry H. Rathbun, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, declared today.

NANKING, June 19--Premier T. V. Soong declared today that 80 per cent of the total Government receipts were being used to finance the huge Chinese National Army. He said it would be impossible to curb disastrous inflation here without internal peace.

Although buying pressure for the fall season has eased somewhat, the New York market for women's and children's apparel still is marked by activity attributed to late-comers and buyers who stayed over to fill their needs, a survey of the trade showed yesterday.

The inquisitive commercial air traveler who has wondered about his whereabouts during long crosscountry flights will have his curiosity satisfied promptly by a device introduced in the Dixieliner, a Douglas DC-4 being operated by Chicago Southern Airlines.

PARIS, June 19--Foreign Minister Georges Bidault was chosen President of the Provisional Government today. The office is the equivalent of the Premiership, but has borne this new designation during the constitutional interregnum.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The National Housing Agency ordered into effect today a subsidy program designed to stimulate production of structural clay products essential to the achievement of the Government's emergency housing program.

Governor Dewey, Mayor O'Dwyer, other public officials and representatives of five colleges went on a forty-six-mile housing tour from 10:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. yesterday and outlined permanent and emergency projects that will accommodate 14,000 persons at a cost of $38,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 19--Defense counsel for Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch made a new plea today that the court allow ten United States witnesses to appear on the Chetnik leader's behalf in his treason and war crimes trial here, but the presiding judge cut him off and did not even answer, while the prosecutor objected angrily to the proposal.

A new 100-foot-wide strip of sand bordering the summer houses at Oak Beach along Fire Island Inlet has emerged as the first completed Long Island anti-erosion project on the schedule envisioned by the special Legislative Committee which reported on the subject in February, 1945.
Joe Louis' victory set off a celebration in Harlem last night that was turned into a combination of New Year's Eve. V-J Day and July 4.
The cost of moving household goods and commercial furniture goes up today about 10 per cent in the metropolitan area--for those who can find a place to which to move.
The request of a Philadelphia corporation for a franchise was denied at the meeting of the National Hockey League's board of governors at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.
President Truman pledged American support yesterday to whatever international health organization is established by the United Nations.

Twelve hundred New York maritime workers, members of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, voted unanimously last night in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street, to hold a strike vote from July 1 to July 31. The gathering was one of several held in ports throughout the country.

"That was the kid's last fight." With these words, Billy Conn, the beaten challenger, announced his retirement from the ring shortly after he had been stopped in the eighth round by Joe Louis last night.

An irregularly shaped plot at the southwest corner of Flatbush Avenue and East Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Boine T. Johnson and Patrick J. Grace Jr. to a client of Meyer Weinstein, attorney, who plans to improve it with a one-story taxpayer and two-family houses.

NEW DELHI, India, June 19-- Differences between Mohandas K. Gandhi and a considerable element of the Congress party's Working Committee appeared tonight to have further complicated the Indian political picture.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Disappointment mingled with hope that the Soviet Union might change its attitude after further discussion was the essence of reaction in the capital tonight to Soviet insistence that the veto be retained in any plan for international control of atomic energy.

Though halibut is seldom in as abundant supply as other members of the flounder family, to which it belongs, surprisingly enough, good quantities of the Pacific fish are coming to market now, the season having opened on May 1, the Fish and Wildlife Service and the Fishery Council report.

The International Game Fish Association, which records all of the top sporting catches throughout the world, has just issued the 1946 list of world game-fish records, and for those of you who are going to try hard this season here are a few of the weights you must exceed in order to win, with the line size employed in taking them.

PORTLAND, Me., June 19 (AP)-- Mrs. Beatrice Ashley Chanler of 59 East Fifty-fourth Street, New York, died today aboard a New York-to-Portland train while on the way to her Islesboro (Me.) summer home.
Temporarily, at least, France has weathered a political crisis which was regarded as a test of the ability of the newly elected Constituent Assembly to agree on a government.
Views illustrating five centuries of Paris are shown in an exhibition of old prints at the new Emmerik Gallery, 662 Lexington Avenue.

The first sign of hot weather generally is a harbinger of another frosted extravaganza at the Center. Mindful of the six-year growth of a loyal clientele at the citadel of ice spectacles, Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz are loath to disappoint them. Accordingly, they will bring the latest of the species there tonight, "Icetime."

Assistant Corporation Counsel Edward A. Heffernan, who as an assistant district attorney in Kings County took part in the investigation of the slaying of a patrolman in Coney Island during a hold-up, admitted yesterday that he made "recommendations" that resulted in the prosecutor's office making a "series of payments" to a convict who appeared as a State witness in a murder trial.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- President Truman conferred today with the Army and Navy Munitions Board on industrial preparedness in the event of another emergency.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- The State Department announced tonight that $32,000,000 in Hungarian gold plundered by the Germans and now held by American forces in Germany would be returned to the Hungarian Government.

CHICAGO, June 19--A rise in prices followed by peak production resulting in a flood of goods if price controls are lifted was predicted today by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Good Association, in an address before the association's Controllers' Congress convention.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday posted June 27 for opening bids on a $5,000,000 emergency housing bond issue dated June 1, 1946, and to mature on June 1, 1948 to 1952. Interest is not to exceed 1.2 per cent.

TOKYO, June 19--Sir William Webb, Australian presiding justice of the International Military Tribunal, warmed prosecution and defense counsel today that unless they were able to speed up the presentation of testimony and cross-examination the court would be compelled to take the proceedings into its own hands and "judge by the results."

CHICAGO, June 19--A much larger trade was on in oats futures today on the Board of Trade, selling by houses with eastern connections and professional traders causing September to dip 1/8 cent a bushel and November cent under the ceiling at one time, but the loss was quickly recovered on short covering and the finish was unchanged with all deliveries at the ceiling.

BUFFALO, June 19--Calling upon librarians to help make this continent "book conscious," Charles R. Sanderson of the Toronto Public Library asserted that the world had a final chance, through books, to avert disaster. Public opinion could be molded for peace, he said.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Key opponents of the 'teen-age draft opened a last-ditch fight today to prevent a Senate-House conference agreement on the Selective Service extension bill, although a deadlock appeared to have been broken by a proxy cabled from Honolulu by an absentee conferee.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP)--Bill Veeck, former owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, said tonight he and his associates were prepared to take over immediate operation of the Indians, and that he was "hopeful that the sale will be completed in two or three days."
Owners of six Harlem tenements were fined a total of $525 yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Municipal Term Court for allowing their buildings to be in dirty and unsafe condition.

WITH a remarkable sense of timing Messrs. John Durant and Edward Rice have produced a book on the Manly Art of Self Defense which Duell, Sloan Pearce have published just when interest in pugilism is at its most acute stage, the period of the Louis-Conn fight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Thursday, June 20--The Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, was received last night by King Farouk and requested asylum from the Egyptian royal house, it was announced early today in an Egyptian communique. It can be stated... authoritatively that asylum will be granted in accordance with ancient Moslem traditions of hospitality.
There is little doubt that the Senate will confirm Gen. Mark Clark in the permanent rank of Major General, as its Military Affairs Committee has now unanimously recommended.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19--Although the shooting war is over, there is still a big job for American Red Cross workers to do in foreign lands, especially now that dependents of service men are going overseas, Lieut. Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Army Public Information, declared here tonight.
CHICAGO, June 19--The ranks of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, united until now, today split into two factions on the question of whether the nation should continue price control.

Buying of distant months by leading commission houses, and continued trade covering in near months, carried cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to net gains on the day of 9 to 36 points on active months yesterday.
FORT MADISON, Iowa, June 19 --Walter A. Sheaffer, founder and since 1938 chairman of the board of the W.A. Sheaffer Pen Company of this city, died here today at the age of 78.
PRETORIA, South Africa, June 19--Premier San Christiaan Smuts, speaking in the Union House of Assembly, today said that the world was marching to disaster which "can be halted only by making peace."

BUENOS AIRES, June 19--Argentine funds totaling 2,575,465,000 pesos--roughly $643,866,000--on deposit in a New York Federal Reserve Bank and frozen by the United States Treasury in 1944, are likely to be released shortly as a result of the Argentine Government's request to Ambassador George S. Messersmith.

Single housing units for veterans now on the real estate market for $10,000 or less under Federal Housing Administration priority requirements are "inadequate relief for the former service man's housing shortage," it was charged yesterday by John Dwyer, housing representative for the American Veterans' Committee.

CLEVELAND, June 19--W.E. Reynolds, Federal Commissioner of Public Buildings, left here tonight for New York to begin a room-toroom survey of all Governmentleased space with a view to releasing offices more rapidly for private tenants.

Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick, member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, received yesterday the National Achievement Award of Chi Omega, national collegiate sorority, at a luncheon in the Colony Club, Park Avenue and Sixty-second Street. Mrs. McCormick was cited in February by the Women's National Press Club as one of the ten outstanding women of 1945.

The final form of the bill to extend price control falls far short of relieving chaotic conditions in the lingerie industry, according to a statement issued yesterday by the board of governors of the Lingerie Manufacturers Association.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers stretched their mastery over last-place Philadelphia to eight straight games today as Virgil (Fire) Trucks blanked the Athletics, 3 to 0, by scattering a half dozen hits.
Six Girl Scout members of Troop 65 became celebrities aboard the S.S. Brazil three hours before the battle-gray United States Lines vessel left Pier 54 yesterday for Southampton.

Participation of four star athletes from the Grand Street Boys Association in the national A.A.U. track and field championships at San Antonio on June 28-29 was threatened yesterday by the refusal of Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, president of the association, to sanction any contributions toward their expenses because of "the Jim Crow practices prevailing in" the Texas city.

Hyacinthe Ringrose of 53 West Eighty-fifth Street, lawyer with offices at 135 Broadway, whose name was known to many New Yorkers through the letters he had written to newspapers during the last twenty years, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers, N.Y., after six months of failing health and a serious cardiac condition which developed two weeks ago. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The Rumanian Government has made the point that the Soviet Union has not objected to conditions in the country concerning which the United States and Great Britain have protested.
JERUSALEM, June 19--More hopeful signs that the five captive British officers--with a sixth suspected as having been kidnapped though officially posted as missing --night shortly be surrendered...

Urging all men and women to write to their members of Congress and demand passage of the PepperNeely bill calling for an appropriation of $100,000,000 for cancer research, Mrs. Francis J. Rigney, former Commander of the Field Army, New York City Cancer Committee, said yesterday that funds must also be raised in New York for construction of a model hospital for care of advanced cancer patients.
Charges of racial discrimination against a New York City realty concern in a case involving the employment of a Negro were settled by the State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday.

Lady Astor intends to continue her campaign to establish the right of women to go to the House of Lords, she disclosed yesterday in an interview at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel on the eve of her return to her adopted country.

Willis Smith of Raleigh, N.C., president of the American Bar Association, said here yesterday that the conduct of the Nuremberg war criminal trials and the ultimate findings of the court deserved the full support of American lawyers.

After a survey of alleged newsstand irregularities in the Times Square area, the Department of Licenses learned that several newsstand owners were in Florida, Commissioner Benjamin Fielding disclosed yesterday. In addition, thirty-three licensees in the section could not be found near their stands.

YESTERDAY was the day scheduled for Joe Louis' biggest fight. The authority for that statement was the Brown Bomber himself. It was a month ago that the champion, an amused glint in his eyes, confided: "The big ...
Miss Henie and her partner have brought another pleasant skating show to the Center Theatre.

The Welfare Council of New York City recommended yesterday to the City Department of Welfare that the extent and qualfty of services provided to residents of voluntary homes for the aged should determine the board rates charged by such institutions.
PITTSBURGH, June 20--Steel fabricating companies are still beset with a hangover from two major strikes--the steel and bituminous coal shutdowns.

The conference method of adjusting rates and coordinating railroad service is "more important from the standpoint of the public interest than from the standpoint of the railroads' interest," John E. Tilford, vice presi- ...
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)-- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Fred M. Vinson of Kentucky to be Chief Justice of the United States.

SEOUL, Korea, June 20--In an effort to halt illegal conversion of United States dollars into Korean yen and at the same time to eliminate black market traffic, the military occupation authorities here are tightening controls and rigidly interpreting the existing regulations dealing with currency, it was announced today.

Citing the nation's record production boom under price controls, Zenas L. Potter, chief of the Congressional relations division of the Office of Price Administration, warned yesterday that abolition of price control will bring economic collapse and a serious threat to the free enterprise system.
For the fourth time, New York harbor welcomed yesterday a new Grace Line vessel bearing the name Santa Barbara.
LONDON, June 20--Britain is not at present planning to carry any further the controversy with Rumania over the elections there, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)--A $341,890,000 Interior Department appropriations bill, nearly twice as large as was voted by the House, won Senate passage late today after opponents of public power lost a fight to halt two Federal electrical projects in the West and Southwest.

The excess reserves of the seventeen reporting New York City member banks of the Reserve System fell very sharply in the period ended on last Wednesday, reflecting the $1,800,000,000 cash redemption of Treasury bonds which took place on Saturday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20--Dr. Nikander Strelsky, Associate Professor of Russian and of Comparative Slavonic Literature at Vassar College, died of a heart attack this morning at Saranac Lake where he, with Mrs. Strelsky, was spending his spring-term leave of absence. His age was 53.

Aided and abetted by sparkling support at bat and in the field, unbeaten Kirby Higbe staggered to his seventh pitching triumph of the season as the league-leading Dodgers turned back the Pirates, 7 to 3, at Ebbets Field yesterday to set the stage for their showdown week-end series with the secondplace Cardinals, who move into Flatbush tonight.

The basic real estate tax for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be $2.70 on each $100 of assessed valuation. Controller Lazarus Joseph indicated yesterday in a report to the City Council, which will fix the rate next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The World Bank took a major step toward its operational stage today when Eugene Meyer, president, announced the schedule of calls upon member nations for the funds with which the institution will conduct its direct lending operations.

The revolt in Tammany against its domination by Edward V. Loughlin, leader; Bert Stand, secretary, and Clarence H. Neal Jr., chairman of its elections committee, broadened yesterday when twelve Assembly district leaders ...

NEW DELHI, India, June 20-- The arrest of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, President-designate of the All-India Congress party, by Kashmir State authorities today resulted in the adjournment indefinitely of the Congress party's Working Committee, which was considering the Viceroy's proposals for an interim popular Government.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Marshal Hale Fisher of Merry Hill, Woodside, Calif., of the engagement of Mrs. Fisher's daughter, Miss Margaret Hitchcock, to Lieut. (j.g.) Douglas Carver, USNR, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Nickels Carver of New York.

Mayor O'Dwyer accepted yesterday the resignation of William Reid as a member of the Board of Transportation, swore in William H. Davis, former chairman of the War Labor Board, as his successor, and then swore in Mr. Reid as a Deputy Commissioner.

A fleet filly named Bridal Flower gave Colonel E.R. Bradley his first victory in the long history of the Gazelle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday and in so doing upset the equanimity of the handicappers --not to mention most of those in the crowd of 20,076 out to see the fifty-first and richest running of the event.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 20 --After the first two rounds of the forty-fourth annual metropolitan amateur championship now in progress at the Essex County Country Club, the home State golfers hold a dominating lead on the other districts, with four surviv-...
WASHINGTON, June 20--Senate House conferees reached agreement today on a nine-month extension of Selective Service from July 1, with 18-year-old youths made entirely exempt from future draft calls.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20-- The threat of communism will be ultimately faced and defeated, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said here this afternoon in the chief address of the 209th commencement exercises of the university at which 169 degrees were awarded to both undergraduate and graduate students, from twenty-six States, the District of Columbia and five foreign countries.
Another of this port's familiar pre-war vessels is now being reconverted to resume her peacetime role.

JERUSALEM, June 20--Jewish extremists of the Irgun Zvai Leumi were holding captive tonight five British officers following the escape earlier in the day of Maj. H.P. Chadwick, who had been abducted on Tuesday in Jerusalem.

MONTREAL, June 20, (U.P.)-- Fred Rose, 38-year-old Canadian member of Parliament, and reputed to be a Communist, was sentenced today to six years imprisonment for conspiring to give secret information to Russian agents.
Autumn millinery took its first bow of the season yesterday afternoon when Peg Fischer presented her collection for the press in the penthouse of the St. Regis Hotel ...

A three-room model apartment cheerfully decorated within the rounded confines of a Quonset hut raised the enthusiasm of soldiers, veterans and their wives yesterday as they moved into the first eighteen huts to be completed in the Jamaica Bay Houses in Canarsie, Brooklyn.

Control of the birth rate is as important to the maintenance of international peace as control of the atomic bomb, Dr. Djamil Pasha Tutunji, Trans-Jordan observer to the International Health Conference, suggested to that body yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20--Chester Bowles, Stabilization Director, made it clear in a statement today that he would stand firmly against any compromise of the price control issue.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 20-- A resolution urging President Truman to "set in motion such action as may be necessary to bring moral conditions within the armed forces of the United States closer to the Christian moral standards" was passed today by the annual conference of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.

CHICAGO, June 20--The Yankees broke even with the White Sox in a double-header here this afternoon and moved to within six and a half games of the leagueleading Red Sox, who dropped a night game to the Browns in St. Louis.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 20-- John Taylor of Siwanoy, Westchester senior champion, fired a 73 to lead the field of eighty-three players by ten strokes today in the spring tournament of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

No pledges were made to Nathan Spielfogel by the District Attorney's office of Kings County in return for his testimony at the first murder trial of Morris Malinski, Assistant Corporation Coun sel Edward A. Heffernan, a former aide in the prosecutor's office, testified yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20(AP)-- Joe Louis and Billy Conn are not likely to retire from work the rest of their lives on what they net from their world heavyweight championship fight last night.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 20 (AP)-- An official of the Iranian state railways said today that railways in Azerbaijan Province were still in the Russians' control.
PARIS, June 20--After a visit late tonight from former Premier Edouard Herriot, who told him that the Radicals would not participate in his Cabinet, President Georges Bidault said:

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 20 (AP)-- Ben Hogan, the Hershey, Pa., belter and Jimmy Demaret, the grinning gentleman from Houston, Tex., took the lead today in the 1946 Inverness invitation golf tournament on the strength of a pair of red hot putters.

The three-story industrial building at 146-50 West Sixty-third Street, formerly occupied by the Pierce-Arrow Automobile Company and now under lease to Aug. 31, 1946, by Jean Vivaudou, perfumes and cosmetics, has been purchased by Frederick Brown from Gifford Pinchot and from Sidney Newborg, Walter Frank and John H.G. Pell, executors of the estate of Amos R.E. Pinchot.
Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations will reorganize his cabinet within the next few weeks, it was learned last night.
ATHENS, June 20--Conflicting views on the plebiscite on the monarchy issue, now scheduled to take place Sept. 1, were voiced strongly in Parliament and press today.
WASHINGTON, June 20--The House Expenditures Committee took the first Congressional step today to block President Truman's plans for reorganizing the executive branch.
Believers in the year round policy of "peace on earth, good-will toward men" have nobly supported "This, Too, Shall Pass." Without
All that a prizefight can prove, on the face of it, is that one man can hit harder and more accurately than another.
LONDON, June 20--Almost daily now the Moscow radio attacks the plan for a federated Germany that Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin is preparing to place before the Foreign Minister's meeting in Paris.
The cost of eating out has begun to rise in some restaurants and at lunch counters as a result of last week's amendment of the price regulation, a city-wide checkup disclosed yesterday.

The stock market suffered yesterday one of the severest breaks in recent years as prices for thinmarket issues plunged as much as 20 points and inroads in the industrial averages ranged to more than 5 points with the composite rate down just above a points.

Governor Dewey, Mayor O'Dwyer, Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing, and Robert Moses, construction coordinator, spent yesterday morning inspecting sites for new housing, school, playground and park projects in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn, where they received first-hand reaction from residents.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 20-- President Bechara el Khury of Lebanon, together with Premier Saadu Munla, War Minister Emir Emgid Arslan and six other high officials arrived this morning in Ankara on the personal invitation of President Ismet Inonu of Turkey, who received them in the Turkish capital with full ceremony.

Although they will receive no help toward expenses from the Grand Street Boys Association, Jim Herbert and Bernie Mayer, two of that club's four eligibles for the National A.A.U. track and field championships, are expected to make the trip to San Antonio, Texas, for the meet next Friday and Saturday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN Germany, June 20, (U.P.)--Thirteen prominent American editors and newspaper executives are scheduled to arrive here on Saturday for a 24-day tour of the European theatre and the American zone.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The Socialist party convention's labor committee called today for independent political action by labor in cooperation with other progressive groups and declared "labor must free itself from the coattails of the parties of the bosses."
CAIRO, Egypt, June 20--The Egyptian Government made it very plain tonight that while the Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Hus

A four-story store and loft building and a three-story store and apartment building at 116 University Place and 32 East Thirteenth Street have been sold by Fred H. Mertens, as trustee, to a client of Herbert Charles Co. for investment.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The Senate's Finance Committee today reported out a bill extending the life of the Sugar Act of 1937 beyond June 30. The bill is identical with that approved by the House on Monday except that the measure extends the act for three years instead of the one year limit set by the House.

Marlboro Estates, Inc., sold the five-story apartment house at 2409 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of Farber-Wittman, Inc., and Paul P. Zinner, brokers in the transaction, for cash above mortgages of $80,250.

Virginia Swantek, 12 years old, was playing a game of ping-pong doubles at the Children's Aid Society's Sloane Center, 630 East Sixth Street, when Miss Dorothy Lewis. director, told her she had been chosen as the winner of the eighth annual "amiable child" award.

LONDON, June 20--The Russian proposal to destroy and outlaw the atomic bomb is under consideration here today, with unofficial reaction pointing toward opposition. At the same time there is no tendency to brush the proposal aside as unworthy of careful study.
TOKYO, Friday, June 21 (AP)-- The Japanese Diet, which heard yesterday a precedent--making message from Emperor Hirohito, reconvened today for the administrative speech of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

The Senate and House conferees on price control extension have acted wisely in deciding not to reveal their tentative compromises on special points until agreement has been reached on the entire bill.

Though the chances of getting even a pound of kidneys are worse, if anything, than last week, the news in fresh produce is decidedly good today, presenting a cheerful contrast to the oh-so-empty counters in butcher stores.

Palestine offers the only opportunity for a future to the remnant of the European Jews, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday at a luncheon he sponsored in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for William Rosenwald, national chairman of the $100,000,000 campaign of the United Jewish Appeal.

A side of Greenwich Village usually unseen by the average tourist was shown yesterday, when the Little Garden Clubs of New York staged its first seasonal tour since before the war of local backyard gardens and penthouses.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20--An amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, aimed at extending the prospective provisions of the measure to investors in securities of 1,000 unregistered companies having assets of $3,000,000 and more than 300 security holders, was recommended today to Congress by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

After a searching analysis of Russia's substitute proposal for outlawing the atomic bomb, the United States is standing firm on its stipulation that no great-power veto can block effective and drastic measures against violators.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)-- The nation's wheat crop prospects improved by 7,630,000 bushels the first half of June, but the expected production continues far short of the amount needed to give Americans all the bread and flour they want.

CHICAGO, June 20--Farmers who fail to comply with the Government's order to sell half the wheat delivered to elevators or warehouses for storage space may be fined as much at $10,000 and put in jail for a year.

LONDON, June 20 (AP)--Jack Kramer withdrew today from the Queen's Club tennis tournament because of a blister on his right hand, robbing the event of a looked-for preview of the Wimbledon championships, for which he is seeded No. 2.

The most spectacular air show New York has seen for many years will be put on today, displaying the prowess of the latest Army and Navy planes around the Statue of Liberty and over the Upper Bay, and then repeating in reverse the historic flight that Glenn Curtis made from Albany to New York on May 29, 1910.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, June 20-- The United States Navy, which less than a year ago was doing its best to send all Japanese to the bottom of the ocean, today rescued 3,400 repatriated Japanese soldiers from a reef on which their ship was pounding to pieces.

WASHINGTON, June 20--At a press conference today Chester Bowles implied a little more strongly than on previous occasions that he will resign if the price controls extension bill, now moving toward passage, is not made more satisfactory from his viewpoint than the House or Senate version is. But that threat is not what is worrying Congress.

France, as a major victim of the war, situated at the crossroads of east and west, was nominated yesterday by Russia to head the United Nations' urgent new subcommission to investigate the devastated areas of the world and report on reconstruction.

BERLIN, June 20--The fact is gradually leaking out that the sharp increases in the influx of infiltrators in the American zone is posing an aggravated problem for welfare authorities and there are indications that the disturbances reported in Poland may produce an acceleration in the immediate future, complicating the situation.

The unhappy Austrians, already stripped of a great part of their industrial plant by the Russians, have received a fresh blow in the shape of a demand from the Allied Control Council in Berlin for the return of German investments in Austria.

CLEVELAND, June 20--The National Association of Building Owners and Managers went on record today in favor of early removal of limitations on construction of new residential and commercial buildings by private interests.
WASHINGTON, June 20-- Former President Hoover blamed mistaken identity today for his public misunderstanding with William L. Clayton, Assistant Secretary of State, over their tele- ...

WASHINGTON, June 20--Development of a "master plan" to cope with the rapidly mushrooming traffic in a radio spectrum that has increased from a pre-war limit of 300,000 kilocycles to 30,000,000 kilocycles was disclosed today by the Federal Communications Commission.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Austin of Detroit have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Marianne, to Henry Lawrence Chisholm Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chisholm of Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

In his long and brilliant career Joe Louis has delivered many damaging punches against the heavyweights he encountered on his climb to the top and in the twenty-two successful defenses he has made of the world heavyweight title.

WASHINGTON, June 20--Near1y 65 per cent of the approvals for construction projects of the nonhousing type as granted by the Civilian Production Administration for the New York area between March 26 and May 30 were for commercial projects such as service stations, office buildings and restaurants.

UTICA, N.Y., June 20--Any permanent reduction in the quality of the American diet to feed other peoples is not to the best interest of the people of this country, declared C. Chester Du Mond, State Agriculture Commissioner, today speaking before the New York State Association of Small Loan Companies at its annual meeting in Hotel Utica.
CHICAGO, June 20--Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade today was confined to a few sales of September, November and December oats at ceiling prices, with the close at the top.

WASHINGTON, June 20--David A. Morse, approved today by the Senate Committee on Education and Labor for his new position in the Labor Department, will have to possess the wisdom of a Socrates and a Solomon combined to reconcile the conflicting forces whiich will meet belligerently in his office.

Laurence Olivier has cabled Story Productions that Lawrence Evans, general manager of the Old Vic theatrical troupe, would go to Hollywood to discuss the deal offered this week by the film company to Mr. Olivier, his wife, Vivien Leigh, and the Old Vic company to appear in Story's projected picturization of the Taylor Caldwell best-selling novel, "This Side of ...
A joy ride in a stolen automobile proved a tragic lark early yesterday morning for 14-year-old Charles Goodman of 240 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn.

Count Antoine de Sala, former member of the French Embassy in Washington and a well-known art expert, died on Wednesday at his estate, Villa Liliput, in Antibes, France, it was learned here yesterday. His age was 70.

WASHINGTON, June 20--A fixed basic price of 23 cents a pound has been set by the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and France for the purchase of natural rubber from British, Netherland and French Far Eastern sources for the period from July 1 through December 31, it was announced tonight.

President Truman has asked Congress to make available at once the remaining $465,000,000 of our second $1,350,000,000 commitment to the work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20--The most important task confronting Red Cross societies throughout the world is to aid suffering people wherever help is needed, without regard to race, religion or nationality, and without interference from personal sympathie or antipathies, the American Red Cross was told ...

Army experts believe that effective inter-continental rockets will not be developed for ten to fifteen years, Maj. Gen. Robert W. Hasbrouck, Deputy Chief of Staff for Army Ground Forces, said last night.
WASHINGTON, June 20--Primary market prices continued their advance during the week ended on June 15, increasing 0.3 per cent.

LONDON, June 20--The Polish Government protested to Britain today about the dissemination of international news in Warsaw by the Briitsh Embassy there and asked that the embassy be instructed to distribute news concerned solely with events in Britain.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 20--A universal adult education program, involving 60,000,000 men and women, to develop competent citizens in the United States was urged today by Dr. Mortimer J. Adler of the University of Chicago. Unless this is done, he said, real democra- ...

PARIS, June 20--The possibilities of a peace conference to settle the turbid affairs of uneasy Europe became considerably more distinct today when the Council of Foreign Ministers reached conditional agreements for the eventual evacuation of occupation forces from Italy and Bulgaria and took steps toward reaching a temporary solution governing the status of the Italian colonies.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)-- The United States Chamber of Commerce put itself on record today against the Administration's compulsory national health insurance bill.

TOKYO, Friday, June 21 (AP)-- Japan's No. 1 propagandist testified yesterday that he inflamed the public against the United States and Britain in the delicate months before Pearl Harbor, although he himself considered neither an enemy.

The Club Harmony Flat Foots, a foursome of Bronx policemen costumed as singing waiters, won last night the final competition in the twelfth annual American ballad contest for barber shop quartets sponsored by the Department of Parks. The finals were held on the Mall in Central Park.
The Negro Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday was asked "to stop begging and pay for what it wants." Frank L. Stanley, publisher of The Louisville (Ky.) Defender and president of ...

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 20-- Continuing the fine golf which brought her a 79 in the first round, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches shot a 77 today for a total of 156 and a 2-stroke lead in her defense of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Essex Fells Country Club.

The broadbill swordfish are now making an appearance off Montauk and although they are not reported in great numbers their appearance at this time promises a fair season for the heavy tackle enthusiasts.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The Department of Commerce predicted today that capital investment and loans by the United States to foreign countries would reach a peak and level off within the next year or two and that imports of goods and services into this country should mount steadily after that time under the impetus of debt repayments by foreign Governments.
Two Park Avenue corners in the upper Nineties were purchased yesterday by separate building syndicates which plan future development of the properties.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 20-- Spokesmen for management, labor and the public, opening a four-day conference of the Tamiment Social and Economic Institute at Camp Tamiment tonight, agreed that the country needed a change in its labor policy and debated what that policy should be.

Mrs. Geraldine Becket, widow of Dr. Frederick Mark Becket, inter nationally known metallurgist who died Dec. 1, 1942, jumped or fell to her death yesterday, according to the police, from a window of her seven-room apartment on the tenth floor of 29 Washington Square West.

BAD KISSINGEN, June 18 (Delayed)--Louis Ferdinand, Prince of Prussia and grandson of Kaiser Wilhelm II, said today: "If the Italian people want to be rid of the monarchy and have a republic, it is well."

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20--The Rev. Dr. John Stuart Conning, who retired in 1932 as secretary of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., and as superintendent of its department of Jewish work, died here today in his home, 1 Highland Terrace. His age was 84.
The first two post-war television receivers to be produced by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation were shown yesterday at a press preview at the company's offices here.
LOS ANGELES, June 20(AP)-- Death of an Encino farmer named Will H. Hays caused release by an undertaker today of an erroneous announcement that the former movie censorship director was dead.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP)--Sam Zoldak shut out the Boston Red Sox, 2 to 0, tonight on four hits and the St. Louis Browns swept the three game series. Boston's pitcher, Joe Dobson, had nine strike-outs.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 20--A town-wide effort to spur support of the United Nations as an instrument for world-wide peace got under way here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP)-- Derby Gas and Electric Corporation, New York, plans to make loans to three Connecticut subsidiaries for property improvement with proceeds from a proposed stock offering, the company said today in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The first sign of possible settlement of the Hudson Manhattan tube strike developed last night when the company promised Mayors O'Dwyer and the Mayors of three New Jersey cities that it would put into effect any wage increase recommended by the emergency fact finding board appointed by President Truman. It was the first time ...

The Statue of Liberty will probably get a new green inner paint coat for her sixtieth anniversary this fall, it was disclosed yesterday by Charles S. Marshall, National Parks superintendent on Bedloes Island.

MEXICO CITY, June 20 (AP)-- Sam Breadon, president of the St. Louis Cardinals and vice president of the National League, and President Jorge Pasquel of the Mexican League discussed international baseball problems at length today, but declined to say whether they reached any "peace" terms.

Increasing similarity between urban and rural people was predicted yesterday by Dr. F.F. Hill, Professor of Land Economics at Corned University, in an address before the opening meeting of the North Atlantic Regional Conference on Rural Life and Education held at Teachers College, Columbia University.

There should be no barrier to the exchange of nursing personnel between nations other than the professional qualifications of the nurses themselves, Mrs. Elmira B. Wickendon, R.N., only nurse in the United States delegation to the United Nations World Health Conference in the Henry Hudson Hotel, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20-- President Truman held a weekly news conference and had lunch at the Capitol.

NANKING, June 20--A demand for extension of the fifteen-day Manchurian armistice was made today by Gen. Chou En-lai, leading Communist peace negotiator, who said that an indefinite civil war truce should be proclaimed as a preliminary to settlement of outstanding Kuomintang-Communist political issues.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP)--With their smallest home crowd of the season--5,431 paid fans--looking on under threatening skies, the Detroit Tigers threw a barrage of home runs at the Athletics today, scoring seven times on four circuit swats to beat Philadelphia for the ninth straight time, 9 to 2.

Abandoning hope of inducing owners to rehabilitate closed oldlaw tenements to provide temporary housing despite proffered tax exemptions, the city has started a survey preparatory to condemning the buildings and doing the job itself, it was disclosed yesterday.

An Italian countess, now the wife of an American Army major, on her arrival here yesterday on the brideship Thomas H. Barry told how her German captors beat her because she refused to tell them where she had hidden an American flier who had been shot down near her home.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The largest peace-time appropriation ever sought for the Army was asked of Congress today when a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee submitted a budget of $7,091,034,700 for the coming fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, June 20--President Truman indicated today his opposition to giving the military a voice in any mechanism established for controlling atomic energy domestically, but refused to discuss a question whether the United States would consider a compromise solution of its proposal that the great powers forego their veto power in atomic matters.

The concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under George Szell, with Erica Morini as soloist, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium maintained a high level of excellence from beginning to end.

Paul Rodier, senior member of Maison Rodier, a leading French textile designing and manufacturing firm, with headquarters in Paris and a factory in Bohain, France, died in Paris on Tuesday, according to word received here yesterday.

GRINNELL, Iowa, June 20-- Liberal elements among delegates attending the biennial meeting of the Congregational Christian Churches at Grinnell College won the preliminary skirmishes today in seeking to put the General Council on record as to the attitude of the denomination on world and domestic affairs.

After five days of continuous debate, the Economic and Social Council adopted yesterday the draft constitution of the International Refugee Organization to be set up to bring aid to Europe and Asia's homeless.

BELGRADE, Jugoslavia, June 20--The Yugoslav quisling Government's chief of police and security, Dragomir Yovanovitch, on the stand as a defendant in the war crimes trial here today, identified a photograph of Miss Ruth Mitchell, sister of the late Brig.
NUREMBERG, Germany, June 20(AP)--Albert Speer testified today that he had plotted to kill Adolf Hitler with poison gas shot through the Chancellery bunker ventilator in March of 1945.
TOKYO, June 20--Tsunego Baba, publisher of Yomiuri Hochi, one of Tokyo's three leading newspapers officially asked police protection today after an outbreak of general violence.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 20--The National Industrial Advertisers Association was told today to make their No. 1 job that of selling the American economic system to the nation.
CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP)--The name of Bob (Home Town Boy) Hope came to light today in the pending negotiations conducted by Bill Veeck Jr. for purchase of the Cleveland Indians.
The newly formed Hoving Corporation, which plans to acquire common stock ownership of Bonwit Teller, Inc., and to develop a ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP)-- David Unterberg, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission's trading and exchange division, said today the only reason for an offer of a liquor dividend to stockholders of Park Tilford, Inc., in 1943 was to provide a stimulated market in which controlling stockholder David A. Schulte could unload stock.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 20-- Mrs. Harry J. Nevil Jr. of Hudson River, defending champion, and Mrs. Joseph Holleran of Round Hill advanced to the final round of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship today at the Wee Burn Country Club.

Dr. Chaim Kaplan, rabbi of Congregation Knesseth Israel of Sea Gate, Coney Island, and lecturer of Semitic Languages at Yeshiva University in Manhattan, died in his home at 4621 Beach Fortysixth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning after a long illness. His age was 46.

WASHINGTON, June 24--Chester A. Davis, chairman of the Famine Emergency Committee, today hailed the successful end of the "short-term" campaign to feed starving countries overseas, but said that during the brief "breathing space" ahead, the "save-wheat" effort would continue.

The United Nations Security Council gave formal approval yesterday to its new rule of procedure that will enable the president of the Council to relinquish the chair whenever a matter is being considered with which his country is directly connected.

WASHINGTON, June 24--The reply of James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, to President Truman on the Army-Navy merger plan has been delivered to the White House, an authoritative source disclosed tonight. The text has not yet been made public.

ROSWELL, N.M., June 24 (AP) --Mrs. Ella Scott Tarbell, sisterin-law of the late author and humanitarian, Ida M. Tarbell, died today at the age of 87.

HAVANA, June 24--About 600 students from the United States and 100 from Canada will attend Havana University's Summer School, which opens July 8, university officials said today. With many Latin-American students the enrollment is expected to reach 2,500, or more than double that of last year.
Mr. and Mrs. William York Cocken of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Stewart, to John Allen Dillon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dillon of 280 Park Avenue.

The Park Department's fifth season of free, outdoor dancing in parks and playgrounds of the city will be opened on Thursday on The Mall in Central Park. Dean Hudson's orchestra will start the 1946 series of dances, which will be held every night, weather permitting, Mondays through Fridays until Sept. 13.

WASHINGTON, June 24--President Truman appointed Edmond M. Hanrahan of New York today to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, succeeding Ganson Purcell, whose resignation as chairman of the agency was accepted by the Chief Executive to become effective next Monday.

"Are You With It?" is closing down. The musical will give its 264th and final performance Saturday night at the Shubert. Presented by Richard Kollmar and James W. Gardiner, the show started off with a bang when it first opened at the Century on Nov. 10 of last year.
In the largest city in the country nobody is going hungry today, but many foods are scarcer than they were during the war.

The senior tournament tennis season in Greater New York was a long time in getting off the mark, but when finally it was launched yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills the amount of activity was staggering.

The board of directors of American Overseas Airlines, Inc., voted yesterday to propose a three-forone split of its 1,000,000 capital shares to a special meeting of stockholders of record of July 1 to be held here on July 11.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 24 (AP)-- Production and distribution employes of two Toledo breweries, the Buckeye and Koerbers, and seven beer distributors went on strike today.
PITTSBURGH, June 24 (AP)-- President William E. Benswanger asserted today that no one has offered to purchase the Pirates, but he added: "If a bid is made, we'll listen to it."

BOSTON, June 24 (AP)--E.B. Rollin's New Boom staged a fine drive through the stretch today to win the $4,000 North Square Purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Suffolk Downs, before a crowd of 16,874.

Steel output increased last week and the adjusted index (a component of The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity) rose to 127.5 from 115.6 in the previous week. The figure for the week ended June 23, 1945, was 141.3. Ingot production in the week totaled 1,506,770 tons. Mills operated at 85.5 per cent capacity.

The Government of India has lodged charges with the General Assembly of the United Nations that Indians living in South Africa are being discriminated against, and that as a result friendly relations between these two countries are likely to be impaired.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24 (AP)-- Now it's automobile hub caps that have gone to the black market. Newark police disclosed that for several months they have been deluged with complaints from car owners that hub caps have been disappearing from automobiles parked in the downtown area.

WASHINGTON, June 24--Senate and House conferees agreed shortly before midnight on a Price Control Extension Bill under which ceilings would be retained after June 30 on livestock, poultry, eggs, milk, petroleum, tobacco and other products still in short supply.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)-- Airline heads will consider tomorrow a study concluding that ground costs are excessive, with airport workers idle more than half the time, and recommending that the carriers establish a joint company to run terminals for all of them.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Andre De Coppet of 580 Park Avenue on Friday in the French Hospital. Mrs. De Coppet is the former Miss Eileen Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Johnston of Islip, L.I. The child will be named Laura.

The marriage of Miss Janet Barbara Loeb, daughter of Mrs. Albert I. Loeb of the Pierre and the late Mr. Loeb, to Dr. James Alexander Wolff, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Wolff of this city, took place here last evening in the small ballroom of the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Watson Warden 3d of this city, on Wednesday in the Woman's Hospital here. Mrs. Warden is the former Miss Charlotte Adams Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen S. Hubbard of 800 Park Avenue, with whom Mr. and Mrs. Warden have been staying. The child will be named Nancy.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Betty Lee Blum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Robert Blum of 895 Park Avenue, to Edward S. Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Marcus of Dallas, Tex.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 24-- Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin declared today that he believed the practice of picketing a private home was "an invasion of privacy."

The $1,000,000 United States Public Health Service base hospital built in 1942 to serve the Coast Guard and Maritime Service Training Centers at Manhattan Beach will close officially Sunday and will be listed as surplus property with the Public Buildings Administration, it was disclosed yesterday.

Net income of the Aviation Corporation for the three months ended with February was $302,970, equal after preferred dividends to 2 cents each on 5,885,496 shares of common stock, according to the report issued yesterday.

Price relief, which is expected to break the bottleneck in volumeselling muskrat coats, is expected to be granted by the Office of Price Administration this week, according to market reports here yesterday.
An evaluation of European politics and the possibility of a third world war, entitled "After Hitler Stalin?" will be published by the Bruce Publishing Company on July 30.

LONDON, June 24--An American veteran, Richard H. Davis of Columbus, Ohio, who was recently forbidden to settle here with the British wife whom he returned here to marry after his demobilization, received a sixmonth extension of his permitted stay today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 24 (U.P.) --Regular commercial air service between France and South America was re-established today for the first time since the war when an Air France C-54 plane arrived from Dakar. The plane left Paris yesterday. Tomorrow it will go to Buenos Aires and Santiago, Chile.

A two-day showing of wax flowers in both realistic and fantastic shapes opened yesterday in a studio at 24 East Sixty-seventh Street. The display is the result of a hobby started after the first World War by Mrs. Emma Bauer.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 24--India's formal complaint to the United Nations alleging discrimination against Indians in this country has been discounted here, and has produced little reaction.
Christmas themes predominate at the Display Market Week stand, sponsored by the National Association of Display Industries, which will close Friday at the Hotel New Yorker.
