BOSTON, June 24 (AP)--The Braves ran their current victory streak to five straight today when Big Ed Wright blanked the Cubs, 5--0, with a five-hit performance. It was the Tribesmen's second shutout in a row.
WASHINGTON, June 24--The Railway Express Agency asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to permit it to increase its rates in order to meet added payroll and other costs.

Boston sold yesterday $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes due on Nov. 6 at 0.80 per cent plus a premium of $11 to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and Kuhn, Loeb Co. The notes were priced on reoffering to yield 0.65 per cent.

LONDON, June 24--Walter Nash, Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand, said tonight in a broadcast that he believed that the conflicting views of the Soviet Union and the western powers could be resolved, and he attributed Russian's present suspicions to twenty years of anti-Soviet prejudice in the western democracies.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 24-- Despite shortages of material, 3,323 private homes have been started or completed in Nassau County since the first of the year, it was announced here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24-- Randolph Scott and Harry Joe Brown, film producer, have closed a deal with Columbia under which they will make a screen version of Zane Grey's "Twin Sombreros" for that studio next fall.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24 (AP)-- Charley Chaney, 167 , of Baltimore, knocked out Steve Hostek, 168, of Newark, in 2:16 of the fifth round in their scheduled eightround main event tonight at Meadowbrook Bowl.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 24--On July 1 the American zone will enter an "interim" stage between full military occupation by combat troops and the police-force occupation by the American constabulary that will become fully effective on July 1, 1947, Gen. Jaseph T. McNarney announced today.

KARACHI, India, June 24 (AP)-- The State of Hyderabad plans to place orders for industrial machinery to a total value of 3,000,000 ($12,000,000) in the United States and Britain, Nawab Zian Yar Jung Bahadur, Hyderabad Public Works Minister, said today.

NAPLES, Italy, Tuesday, June 25 (AP)--A throng of irate women invaded the city hall at Bitonto yesterday and beat up the Mayor because of the recent poor quality of bread in the city, as food rioting broke out in other municipalities in southern Italy.

The forty-sixth annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America opened last night at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., June 24 (AP)--Dr. W.E. Shaw, president of Illinois Wesleyan University since 1939, today announced his resignation, effective Aug. 1, 1947.

Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade announced yesterday the assignments of four newly elected assistant superintendents. The appointments to the $10,000-a-year jobs will become effective next Monday and the assignments next September.
Construction contracts awarded in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains reached a new record in May, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 24--The United States has asked for changes in Britain's proposed terms of trusteeship for her three African mandates, it was learned today.

MANILA, June 24--Ambassador Edwin W. Pauley feels that the Philippines deserve and could utilize a top priority share in Japanese heavy industrial equipment that as part of Japan's war potential will be distributed among Far East nations suffering occupation damage during the war.

Play in the sixteenth annual Queens interscholastic golf championship started at the Pomonok Country Club, Flushing, yesterday, with Eric Hufschmid of Wilson Vocational, a finalist last year, defeating Bob Biggers of Xavier, 3 and 2.
The House of Representatives has scheduled for today a vote on the compromise Selective Service Bill which was put together last week in a conference committee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP)-- A registration statement for $20,000,000 of twenty-year debentures, due in 1966, and 1,000,000 shares of $1 par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Sunray Oil Corporation, Tulsa, Okla.

A 29-year-old captain in the Army, who served in the southwest Pacific with the Corps of Engineers, was charged yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, with violating the National Stolen Property Act by passing $500 in bad checks.

Arthur Breakstone of Elizabeth, N.J., has purchased the Victoria Hotel at 206 Seventh Avenue, North Asbury Park, N.J., from John E. Cullen.

CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP)--The Cleveland Indians announced today that Tom Ferrick, 200-pound relief pitcher, was being sent to the St. Louis Browns on waivers. A righthander, Ferrick rejoined the Indians early this year after serving in the Navy during the war.
Mayor O'Dwyer swore in Special Sessions Justice Bernard A. Kozicke yesterday to a new ten-year term, in the presence of his family and friends at City Hall.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 24 --Abraham A. Redelheim of New York City was elected president of the National Organization B'nai Zion at the closing session of its annual convention here today. He succeeds Louis Lipsky.

TOKYO, June 24--In February, an attempt to estimate the yen's value resulted in the conclusion that it was worth between 1.25 and 2.5 cents. Today, under the same method, its worth is put at approximately .76 of a cent.

Usually it's the parents who attend the high school graduation of their children. Not so, however, tomorrow night at the New Lots Evening High School in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- President Truman spoke at ceremonies swearing in Fred M. Vinson as Chief Justice of the United States.

The Grace liner Santa Paula, completing her last voyage as a war bride transport, arrived at Pier 97, North River, yesterday from Le Harve with 169 wives and nineteen children of American service men and 179 other passengers.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 24-- The National Labor Office has authorized increases of 10, 15 and 25 per cent in the stevedores' wages, which range from $60 to $120 a month. The Contejer textile mills in Medellin have increased wages 15 per cent.

The Security Council refused by a 7-4 vote yesterday to order members of the United Nations to break diplomatic relations with the Franco regime in Spain.
Boris M. Stanfield, Assistant Professor of Economics at Columbia University, leaves today for Havana, where he will teach two courses in the University of Havana's summer session.

William E. Hill, 20 years old, of 97-19 Northern Boulevard, Corona, a former Marine who lost his right leg in combat at Guadalcanal, and two of his neighborhood companions were charged yesterday with robbery, assault and larceny in a Queens County Grand Jury indictment.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 24--A rubber-for-wheat trade between Argentina and Brazil was negotiated today.
PARIS, June 24--Mrs. W.B. Olmstead, director of American Relief for France, summarized at a reception today American aid in this country.

PARIS, June 24--Francis Ambriere, critic, historian, newspaper man and former war prisoner, received the Goncourt Academy's 1940 prize today for "Les Grandes Vacances," his book describing five years in a German prison camp in Poland.

Half the retail butcher shops in this city remained closed yesterday and the others had almost no meat to sell. Poultry, still available in some stores, continued to get scarcer and some fish markets ran out of supplies before the day's end because of heavy buying by housewives.

To help Italian clothing workers help themselves, members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, have contributed $275,000 toward a $500,000 fund for construction of three and possibly four cooperative clothing and shirt factories in Italy.
New York felt the hottest weather of the year yesterday as the temperature reached 89 degrees at 4:15 P.M. As if tired by its climb, the mercury then faltered, but by 6 o'clock was back at 89.

NAPERVILLE, Ill., June 24 (AP) --The engineer of a Burlington Railroad flier was held for the grand jury on a charge of manslaughter today on recommendation of a coroner's jury investigating the rail collision of April 25 in which forty-six persons perished.
PATERSON, N.J., June 24-- Bob Trocolor, former halfback of the Football Giants, has been appointed coach of the Paterson Panthers of the American Football League, it was announced today.

BALTIMORE, June 24 (AP)--Baltimore City, reporting its returns early, gave Gov. Herbert R. O'Conor tonight a lead of more than 13,000 votes over veteran United States Senator George L. Radcliffe for Maryland's Democratic Senatorial nomination.

A guidance plan for veterans interested in sales careers was initiated last night at the New York City Veterans Service Center, 500 Park Avenue, under sponsorship of the Sales Executives Club. WEST NYACK, N.Y., June 24 ----Miss Patricia Hernon Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Murray of this place, was married this morning in the Roman Catholic Shrine of St. Anthony in near-by Nanuet, to William J. McIlvain, son of William J. McIlvain of Chicago and the late Mrs. McIlvain.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 24 --An amateur, Johnny Sierge, stole the show today in the weekly pro-amateur golf competition held at the Essex Country Club. He knocked out a three-under-par 69 on his own ball.

The mastery that Dave Koslo exercises over the Pirates came to the rescue of the Giants yesterday. The stocky little southpaw, Manager Mel Ott's best bet against any rival these direful days and virtually a sure thing against Pittsburgh, lifted his team out of the cellar by hurling a five-hit shutout as the Giants won, 4 to 0.

KANSAS CITY, July 14 (AP)-- Amateur Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, out-stroked a field that included the best professionals in the country to finish first in the $20,000 invitation Victory Bond golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 274, fourteen strokes under par. TRENTON, N.J., July 16--A State rent control bill, which would freeze New Jersey residential rentals as of June 1 and require landlords to appeal to county tax boards for increases, was drafted today by Governor Walter E. Edge and Republican legislative leaders.

In an effort to speed up rail shipments of grain to the Port of New York for trans-shipment to famine areas of Europe, United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey filed civil suits yesterday against seven railroads having terminals in the harbor area.
Two-thirds of the sales clerks at Macy's Parkchester store in the Bronx failed to report for work yesterday as picket lines established by former Macy drivers were extended to the branch shop.

Comdr. William L. Maloney, Coast Guard hearing officer, dismissed yesterday a charge of misconduct against Capt. Frank H. Haas, acting master of the Liberty ship Ada Rehan, after the 47-year-old ship's officer voluntarily surrendered his chief mate's license for cancellation.

The thirteen-story apartment house at 500 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-fourth Street, has been sold by Alexander Hirsch, operator, after an ownership of three years, to the 500 West End Avenue Corporation.

The five-story, sixty-family apartment building at 335 Fourth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Estra Realty Comparry from the A. L. Operating Corporation through Louis Katz, broker. The property is assessed at $170,000 and title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation. The purchaser was represented by Louis A. Brown, attorney.
LONDON, July 16--The House of Commons upheld tonight by a vote of 271 to 137 the Labor Government's refusal to accept an inquiry into the British Broadcasting Corporation.

HELENA, Mont., July 16--Leif Erickson ran powerfully tonight in his rival's home city to win a lead of more than 2,000 votes in early returns from today's primary in which Burton K. Wheeler, backed by President Truman, sought Democratic renomination as United States Senator.

ATLANTA, July 16--Candidates for Governor and twenty-six other State offices, as well as for the ten Georgia seats in the House of Representatives, ended today campaigns which brought some of the most bitterly contested political races in recent State history.

Pre-natal treatment that cuts labor time by 40 to 69 per cent and alleviates extreme labor pains during childbirth was outlined yesterday at the fiftieth convention of the American Osteopathic Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CUTTTYHUNK, Mass., July 16-- The legion of surfcasters who have never stopped trying but never have realized their ambition to take a striped bass might do well to plan a trip to this island, for we can think of no place more certain to bring about a realization of this ambition.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP)--Bobby Feller blazed his fast ball past seven Red Sox today to raise his season's strike-out total of 202 as the Indians trounced Boston 6-3, before 33,142 paying fans and 688 service guests at Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, July 16--In preparation for resuming the draft in September, President Truman directed today that only men aged 19 through 29 be called up, and Selective Service all but abolished the principle of the industrial occupational deferment.

JERUSALEM, July 16--The Jewish National Council called on the Jewish community of Palestine today to engage in a one-day general strike tomorrow in sympathy with the 1,600 men detained at Rafa, who have gone on a hunger strike.

The first break in soaring meat prices since Government controls were abolished on June 30 was revealed yesterday as a sharp decline in retail and consumer buying was evident. Also accumulating stocks found wholesale markets "glutted" with beef and pork and top prices were down from 5 cents to 9 cents a pound.

The British Foreign Office announced yesterday that discussions with American authorities in Berlin will begin soon to work out closer economic relations between the British and American zones in Germany.

RYE, N.Y., July 16--A sparkling finish, under spinnaker, in today's second race and the third official contest of the series, ended an otherwise drab afternoon for six contenders for the Syce Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, off the American Yacht Club today.

CINCINNATI, July 16 (AP)-- Schoolboy Rowe was most of the show today as the Philadelphia Phillies shut out the Cincinnati Reds, 2-0. In marking up his ninth victory against four defeats, Rowe let the Redlegs down with five hits.

AS every fan knows there come those odd moments in ball games when players will do the most unaccountable things. They will leave a base open and go gallivanting off to some other place on the field where they have no business. Or, with equally damaging effect, they'll just stand with their mouths open and go, nowhere at all.

The bitterness of current fac tional conflicts within the National Maritime Union, CIO, was reflected last night in the disclosure that M. Hedley Stone, treasurer and supporter of President Joseph Curran, narrowly won re-election on the basis of evidence submitted by a famous handwriting expert.

The fires are bright and the kilns are hot again in brick plants all the way from Newburgh to Albany. After many years in the doldrums the industry in the Hudson River valley is entering a new period of high production.

DACHAU, Germany, July 16-- Forty-three German Elite Guard veterans were doomed to die and thirty others, including three generals, received long prison terms today for the slaughter of 900 American prisoners and Belgian civilians during the Battle of the Bulge.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16--Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's last appeal for life was rejected today by the Yugoslav Parliament's Executive Presidium, and he is scheduled to die tomorrow morning before a firing squad.

TOKYO, July 16--Soviet representatives in Japan appeared today to have decided to make a fullfledged issue of the question of the Japanese labor legislation that was proposed by Lieut. Gen. Kuzma Derevyanko at the last session of the Allied Control Council.

VARBERG, Sweden, July 16-- Sweden escaped elimination from the European zone final of the Davis Cup tennis competition when its men's doubles team today defeated Yugoslavia's Draja Mitic and reserve player Josip Pallada in a hotly-contested, five-set match, 6--1, 3--6, 3--6, 8--6, 6--2.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 15--For perhaps the first time in her history, Uruguay has established controls over the foreign and domestic press. Ellsworth's spectacular Arizona filly, U-Time, racked up a wire-to-wire victory in the $25,000 six-furlong Starlet Stakes at Hollywood Park for the unofficial Western juvenile championship. U-Time, clocked in 1:10 1/5, finished two and one-half lengths ahead of Louis B. Mayer's colt Stepfather. Hemet Squaw, a filly, was third. The winner was coupled with Hubble Bubble, who ran fourth. U-Time returned $3.70, $2.60 and $2.40.

Willick's Grove in Linden, N.J., a landmark for more than a century, has been purchased as a site for 250 homes, it was announced yesterday by Weiner Weiner, attorneys for a group of Linden business men who are forming a construction company. The purchase price was not disclosed.

CAMP SHANKS, N.Y., July 22 --When the harbor boat General Yates pulled away from Camp Shanks pier at 3 P.M. today with 1,388 German prisoners of war, the final wartime mission of this came was completed.
Mrs. Robert G. Payne has sold her former residence at 120 East Seventy-eighth Street to a client of Douglas L. Elliman Co. who plans to occupy the property.

New York may justly feel pride in its progress in giving to philanthropic causes in the first six months of this year. A study by the John Price Jones Corporation shows $94,160,497 given in this city, which is more than double the amount for the first half of 1945.

More than any other of the five boroughs of New York City, Richmond's greatness lies in the future. Its estimated population in 1945 was only 183,000 as against Brooklyn's 2,770,000. In area it is twice the size of Manhattan.

New York garment manufacturers who have accepted peak orders for women's apparel for the fall season will be hard pressed to keep prices at their current levels because of impending increases in labor costs, it was learned yesterday.

The Rev. Thomas J. It is part of the tragic story in Palestine that violence of the kind that took nearly fifty lives in a single act of terrorism yesterday in Jerusalem is self-defeating. Greece will ask the United States this week for an advance of at least $500,000,000 on the reparations totaling more than $13,283,000,000 that she has claimed from Germany, Italy and Bulgaria, it was announced here yesterday by Nicholas G. Lely, Greek Minister of Information in the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, July 22--A growing "strike fever" has become evident in India. With Bombay virtually isolated from communications with the outside world and workers in other cities expressing discontent, India now apparently faces its worst labor crisis since the railway strike of 1928.

Reporting that new capital issues by industrial companies have averaged $130,000,000 a month this year, the highest rate since 1931, the monthly bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board says the year's corporate earnings will compare "much more favorably" with those of 1945 than the first quartet's earnings indicated.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP)--American railroads began today an individual presentation of their case for a 25 per cent freight rate increase to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 22--A bill for greatly augmented maternal and child health and welfare services, which for the first year would provide $50,000,000 for maternal and child health services, $25,000,000 for crippled children's services, and $20,000,000 for child welfare services, was reported favorably today by the House Labor Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 22--Yugoslavia will never accept a European peace treaty that does not incorporate Trieste in the Yugoslav Republic, but it will not provoke a war if the forthcoming Paris peace conference decides against it, Sava N. Kosanovitch, the new Yugoslav Ambassador, said here today.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (Reuter)-- Mrs. George Hillyard, who, as Blanche Bingley, won the Wimbledon ladies' tennis title six times between 1886 and 1900, died in her home at near-by Pulborough last night. Her age was 83.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Army investigators have uncovered instances of mass murder by Nazi SS troopers of hundreds of American prisoners of war and defenseless Belgian civilians even more flagrant than the Malmedy atrocities, Lieut. Col. Burton F. Ellis, chief prosecutor at the Malmedy war crimes trial, revealed here today.

LONDON, Aug. 7--Prof. Oscar Lange, Polish Ambassador to the United States and delegate to the Security Council, said here today that Poland counted on AngloAmerican support for a western frontier on the Oder line and would be "very much disappointed" if support were not forthcoming when peace was made with Germany.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 7 (AP)-- Lee Braun of Austin, Tex., erstwhile Army Air Forces gunnery instructor, won the small-gauge title today in the international and national skeet championships at the Capitol City Gun Club, beating Joe Devers, 15-year-old Dayton (Ohio) schoolboy, and Russ Aitken, New York sculptor, in a shoot-off.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7--Russian avi ators and aviation engineers were summoned to exert all their efforts to put the Soviet Union in front of all other nations as the "mightiest aviation power in the world" in an editorial in the Army's newspaper, the Red Star, today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7--Buying by cash and commission houses combined with short covering gave the corn and oats markets a firm undertone on the Board of Trade today. Corn closed at the top with gains of 1 7/8 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel, and oats finished 7/8 to 1 cents up. Feed barley rose to cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7-- Scripto, Inc., of Atlanta, Ga., manufacturer of mechanical pencils, and the West Virginia Water Service Company of Charleston, W. Va., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering 25,000 shares of preferred stock and 290,400 shares of common stock.

The gladiolus made a brilliant entry into New York yesterday when the Eastern New York, the New Jersey and the Connecticut Gladiolus Societies staged the largest display of this flower ever Seen locally at the headquarters of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue.

From aardvarks to zebras, the pre-war inmates of zoos throughout the country can relax. No new foreign importations are going to turn up in the near future to crowd their quarters or to steal their audiences by competing for attention.

The produce concern of YeckesEichenbaum, Inc., said to be the largest receiver of melons in the East, was accused yesterday by the Office of Price Administration of causing chaos in the local melon trade through black market sales of cantaloupes, honeydews, and honeyballs.

A training school unique in American maritime history will open at the National Maritime Union's headquarters in New York later this month with the first of what union officials expect will be a student body of several thousand men.

PARIS, Aug. 7--The Russians have taken another whack at already-battered United States investments in the Danubian countries, it was learned today. They have quietly organized a company, with Swiss participation, to take over the distribution of Rumanian petroleum products in the lucrative Swiss market.

LONDON. Aug. 7--John Foster Dulles said at the final session of the World Council of Churches at Cambridge today that the "process of getting the German people in the next war is already under way." This is because the big powers still look on the Germans as a great war potential, he explained.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 6 (Delayed)--The number of legal marriages in Paraguay is growing and the percentage of illegitimacy is decreasing as a result of an increase in the number of males in the country in relation to females.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (AP)--The second-place Cardinals routed Pittsburgh, 8 to 1, at Forbes Field tonight, burying the last-place Pirates with a twelve-hit barrage. St. Louis narrowed the idle Dodgers' National League lead to a game and a half as a result.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--With Bobo Newsom pitching all the way and personally escorting the winning run home, the Senators downed the Yankees, 4--3, in a twelve-inning thriller before 21,156 fans at Griffith Stadium tonight. The set-up was an ideal one for old Bobo, who, at times, appears to need only a sizable turn-out to do his best work.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 7 (AP)-- Mickey Owen returned from four months with the Mexican League fed up with "a broken contract, bad playing conditions and Mexican food."

NANKING, Aug. 7--Gen. Pai Chung-hsi, China's Minister of National Defense, declared today that the Central Government was still determined to settle the Communist problem by political means as an estimated 100,000 Communist troops were reported to be hammering at the gates of Tatung and Nationalist forces continued their advance in North Kiangsu.

Reports from Long Island Sound, from Rye to Port Washington, indicate that the striped bass fishing has picked up considerably, with plenty of bass ranging from six to twelve pounds being taken by the trollers.

The stock market resumed the forward movement yesterday, with most of the activity coming in a brisk final-hour rally, in which prices of many pivotal issues ended one to three or more points higher at the best levels of the day.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP)--The British steamer Elizabete refused to remove her towlines from the crippled food ship American Farmer despite the wishes of the American owners and contrary to United States naval advice, the captain of the United States destroyer Perry said today.

Whitney's Bright Song, third carrier of the Eton blue and brown silks to win the event since its first running in 1918.

The Scottish clan plaids are invading the college field this season. They are so attractively handled that they are carrying the day. Yesterday it was Franklin Simon's college shop that included them in its showing. They strode into the scene in suits, slacks and robes, to say nothing of dresses worn under warm great-coats.

An appeal for support of the United Service Organizations campaign as a means of popular contribution to the achieving of a just and lasting peace was made yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr. in pledging $150,000 to this cause.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 7 (U.P.) --President Ismet Inonu today approved a new Turkish Cabinet under Premier Recep Peker which includes the Foreign Minister and three other officers of the resigned Saracoglu regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--President Truman was expected by White House advisers to renew his demand for the immediate entry of 100,000 displaced European Jews into Palestine and officially to reject the British partition plan, which was described to Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson today as providing a "ghetto in attenuated form."

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 7--An allnight rain that turned the one-mile Good Time Park track into a strip of ooze today caused officials to postpone until tomorrow the twenty-first edition of the Hambletonian Stake, trotting classic for 3-year-olds. When, shortly after 10 A.M., it became evident that no let-up was in sight, this action was necessitated.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander asserted last night that "there is no justification whatsoever" for charges that New York City policemen are brutal in dealings with Negroes and denounced the "campaign of calumny" that he said certain groups were waging against the department.

Despite Soviet objections, the United Nations Security Council decided yesterday that its membership committee had the right to receive written information from member Governments or from the eight nations that have applied for membership, regarding their suitability for membership.

MADRID, Aug. 7--Largely through efforts of his Bryn Mawr educated wife, Julio Nieto, under death sentence for political activities, has received a reprieve from the Captain-General of the Eighth Military Region, it was learned today. As a result, his case will be reviewed in the Madrid Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP)--A single by Whitey Platt with two team mates aboard in the ninth gave the White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Indians today.

Irving Krinsky, 46 years old, of 226 Rodney Street, Brooklyn, jumped to death early yesterday afternoon from his eighth-floor office at 37 East Twenty-eighth Street after striking his wife, Lena, 45, on the head with a hammer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The Department of Justice said today that authorization for one of its War frauds lawyers to appear before a New Orleans grand jury in the Andrew J. Higgins case must "not be construed as a charge of criminal misconduct."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Legislative activities of the National Boys' Senate ended abruptly late today on a motion to adjourn "so we can go to the ball game."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The British Government has advised the United States that it will not permit any further illegal immigration into Palestine and will henceforth ship all such immigrants temporarily to the island of Cyprus, in the eastern Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Busi ness must give the public a clear explanation of the factors behind current increases in prices and not take the blame for higher living costs which are beyond its control, William K. WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--With the receipt of checks totaling $77,480,375.44 the War Assets Administration today closed two of the largest sales of Government-owned surplus war plants it has made to date.

If the American Medical Association fails to support an investigation into the "quota system" of admitting students to medical schools, the people of the nation will be forced to believe that the AMA is guilty of encouraging its continuance, Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the New York State Assembly, said in a letter made public by him yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 7--The largest turnout in Virginia Democratic primary history renominated Senator Harry Flood Byrd yesterday over Martin A. Hutchinson for a third full term. It was the State's first Senatorial primary contest in twenty-four years.

An upward trend in the number of families seaking help with such problems as family conflicts, unhappy or broken homes, delinquency and financial need was shown in a nine-month report made public yesterday by the family service department of the Community Service Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Advertising schedules of the rug trade are being curtailed by reason of the current manpower shortage in the industry which is reducing production. When expanded advertising budgets were being formulated last year, it was explained yesterday, increased production was anticipated.

Participating in China's indus trialization program, the Westinghouse Electric International Company has contracted with China's National Resources Commission to help build a $35,000,000 electrical products manufacturing plant, William E. Knox, president of the company, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that the Treasury's drive against black-market and other wartime tax evaders apparently had frightened some of the taxpayers.

WINNIPEG, Aug. 7 (AP)--Lanky, bespectacled Ellsworth Vines of Chicago, one of the world's finest tennis players in the early Thirties, took the opening round lead today in the $10,000 Canadian Profes sional Golfers Association open tournament by firing a par-shattering 65 that equaled the 15-yearold Niakwa Golf and Country Club course record.

Both a Democratic member of the City Council and a candidate for Republican nomination for Congress were guest speakers yesterday at a "non-partisan course in practical politics," held at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

PARIS, Aug. 7--An important decision has been reached in Moscow to allow the Four-Power Coal Commission, set up a fortnight ago on the urgent demand of the French Government, to carry out its investigations in the Russian zone of Germany. The frightful effects of atomicbomb radioactivity on humans is revealed for the first time in newsreel footage made by Japanese camera men immediately after the bombing of Hiroshima and which the War Department has now released for public showing.
A new alternative site for the permanent headquarters of the United Nations was outlined yesterday by the Headquarters Commission, replacing one of the fifteen sites proposed July 29.

Tai announces for two of the escort class he has purchased for the account of the Chinese Government. It is planned, he says, to take them to one of China's rivers and use them as floating power plants for Chinese cities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7--The Batavia Metal Products Company, Inc., at Batavia, Ill., with all its subsidiaries which make up the munitions combine being investigated by a Senate committee, has been sold to two New York industrialists, Sidney P. Gorham, a Batavia, company attorney, said today.

OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 7--The Maryknoll Fathers announced today they had elected as their new superior general Bishop Raymond A. Lane of Lawrence, Mass., who spent three years and eight months in a Japanese concentration camp in Manchuria.

Lehman Brothers and associates won yesterday at competitive sale the award of bonds of Cleveland, Ohio, aggregating $3,200,000 with a bid of 101.09 for 1 s, an interest cost of 1.3905 per cent. Other bids ranged in interest cost to 1.4253 per cent. Reoffering will be made today at prices to yield from 0.60 to 1.50 per cent. The bonds mature from 1947 to 1971.

THE immense popularity of "The Snake Pit" would seem to indicate that there are a good many people who may want to read a new book called "Asylum Piece,"* published today. This is a collection of short stories and sketches dealing with men and women in various stages of insanity, told, for the most part, from their point of view.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP)-- Tony Lazzeri, second baseman for the New York Yankees baseball team in the days of Babe Ruth, was found dead in his home at near-by Millbrae today. His age was 42. The body was found by his wife, Mrs. Maye Lazzeri, who had been out of the city on a vacation.

DETROIT, Aug. 7--The expected demand from the rank and file of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, for a cost-of-living bonus to increase wages was delivered today to the International Executive Board of the union in a stinging letter written by Tom Cunningham, president of Local 7, a labor unit within the Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The Senate War Investigating Committee disclosed today that some important documents were missing from its files. David S. Meister purchased from Loft Associates Company the twelve-story loft building at 122-30 West Twenty-seventh Street, on a plot nearly 100 by 100 feet, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

LONDON, Aug. 7--With business showing a small expansion, the stock markets here today generally were firm. WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--Food shortage problems among the Japanese continued to plague Army occupation forces there through June, according to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's summary of conditions in the ex-enemy country. The report, submitted to the War Department, was released here today.

A struggle that will have a decisive bearing on the future of the merchant marine is developing on the eve of the Maritime Commission's public hearing on the future of Pacific operations, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON STREET, at the lower end of Manhattan Island. is today a condemned street. From Rector Street to Battery Place, all the people who live there and run restaurants and spice shops and Oriental bakeries and newspapers have received notice to vacate so that Washington Street can become the approach to the new Brooklyn-Manhattan tunnel.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 10 (Reuter)--The predominantly Hindu Indian Congress party Working Committee, after a threeday debate at Wardha, Central Provinces, tonight reaffirmed its acceptance of the British proposals for a federal union of India, and appealed to the Moslem League to cooperate in making the Constituent Assembly a success.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 10--Man's hope of prolonged vitality and productivity is coming noticeably closer to realization through a process now being utilized here which turns common plants into male hormones. PUERTA DE LA LAGUNA, El Salvador, Aug. 8 (Delayed)--Walther Deininger, the naturalized German who was flown to the United States in a special Flying Fortress in February, 1943, and detained as a potentially dangerous Nazi aide, is back on his magnificent coffee and sugar estate here.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 10 (AP)-- British troops set up new accommodations in a detention camp near Famagusta today, apparently for Jews caught trying to enter Palestine illegally, and the population stirred restively to rumors that the first immigrants would arrive Monday.

AN ambitious and diversified stamp-issuing program has been announced by Colombia's Minister of Communi cations, Luis Garcia Cadena. Eighteen promised postal items include some which will serve to introduce eight illustrious Colombians to philately's gallery.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP)--The will of Gertrude Stein, expatriate American writer, containing bequests to Alice B. Toklas, her friend and companion; the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Yale University Library, was filed for probate in Orphans Court today.

LONDON, Aug. 10--Britain, awaiting President Truman's decision on the plan for a federated Palestine, unofficially served notice today that her warships would intercept, search and arrest vessels of another nation carrying Jewish illegal immigrants to the Holy Land.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The results of primary contests in by-election years always are scrutinized for indications of the probable results in November. One reason for this is that the party winning control of Congress in these off seasons has failed only twice to carry the general elections two years later. And this time the Republicans are conceded their best chance of gaining Congressional control since the Roosevelt landslide in 1932.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP)--Development of airplane-to-land telephone using airborne radio was disclosed today by Bendix Aviation Corporation's radio division.
